unit_learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the basic functions and overarching principles of international environmental law including sustainable development, differentiated responsibility, transboundary harm and global cooperation

Construct and evaluate arguments that survey the effectiveness of international environmental law having regard to the purpose of enforcement and compliance and consideration given to the issue of fragmentation
Appraise the benefits and challenges of the treaty based approach to international environmental law and the role of customary law, jus cogens and erga omnes in constructing legal norms

Recognise and recall the key institutions and actors involved in international environmental law, understand their respective roles in establishing and maintaining global environmental governance and progressing change
Critically examine intersections and interactions between international environmental law and other areas of international law, such as trade, human rights, development assistance.
Produce recommendations for law reform and/or further research needed to address global environmental issues taking into account ethical considerations in the Anthropoence epoch

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Students will spend this time completing the prescribed readings
Students will spend this time preparing for the designated tasks listed for each tutorial

enrolment_rules.description: (Admission to JD and 80cp in LAW or LAWS units at 6000 level or above) or (admission to LLM, MIntTrdeComLaw or MSusDev)

assessments.description: Students will prepare a research essay that analyses a topic of environmental law.
Students will prepare and participate in relevant discussion during tutorials including resolving problem based tasks
Students will submit responses to questions based on a hypothetical scenario

data.subject_search_title: LAWS8060 - Energy and Natural Resources Law
data.description: This unit introduces students to international environmental law and governance, a burgeoning and specialised field of public international law. International environmental law manages the interaction of humankind and the environment from a global perspective. The unit explores the legal response of nation states, international institutions such as the United Nations and other relevant global actors to regulate the transboundary aspects of environmental change. Students will cover the historical development of international environmental law, the need for a cooperative, global response and the effectiveness of sustainable development. Several important treaty regimes covering issues such as ozone depletion, climate change and biodiversity are explored in addition to pivotal international case law and arbitration decisions.
